On Tue, 16 Nov 2004 23:33:48 +0000, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
>
> I would have assumed this sort of thing was solved in this day and age.
> I know I've seen fingerprint identification systems on the TV where an
> operator seems to manually identify certain characteristics and then
> (presumbaly) this data is what gets stored in a database and is thus
> easy and quick to search through. A recent science program on TV showed
> this same approach being used with face recognition in Vegas casinos, in
> order to identify known card counters - a manual operator guides the
> whole process, measuring relative distance between the eyes, etc. So
> yeh, I guess automatic categorisation is still a problem that is out
> there - which is interesting in itself.

Yeah, as far as I know, there's no such thing as a completely automated system.

And what we're doing is just the first cut, dividing the prints into
bins to make the one-to-many search more efficient.

Automated fingerprint recognition is one of the oldest pattern
recognition tasks, but there's still a need to make it better and more
efficient, and it's nice to have a wealth of previous research to
compare results to.

> Watching the animation you posted I found it surprising how successful
> the networks are at zooming in on the critical area of the images -
> where the most distinct identifying features are. Very promising indeed.

Yeah, I was happily surprised at how well our early cuts have been.

> I presume this is using almost the same setup as the shape recognition,
> but with a different set of images? Are you using the same resolution
> for the eye?

It's a very similar setup to the shape recognition experiments, though
we've disabled rotation and are using a 7x7 eye instead of 5x5. 
We'ved tweaked the parameters a bit as well, and Philip has added a
few efficiencies and improvements over the code from the stuff in our
paper.  But it's basically the same stuff.

Derek
